plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub cultivated for its large, showy flowers which bloom in late winter to early spring. The flowers can be single or double and are often red, pink, or white. Native to eastern Asia, it is widely grown as an ornamental plant in temperate regions.
plants.location: East Asia, Cultivated worldwide in temperate zones
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica is the state flower of Alabama, USA, despite originating from Asia.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A perennial flowering plant that blooms in winter and early spring. It produces white to pinkish-green flowers that stand out in the cold months. Native to the mountainous regions of Europe, it is valued for brightening gardens when few other plants bloom.
plants.location: Alps and mountainous regions of Central Europe
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas rose is not related to roses and actually belongs to the buttercup family.

plants.name: Acacia dealbata
plants.description: A fast-growing tree native to southeastern Australia noted for its bright yellow, fragrant, fluffy flowers clustered in spherical heads. It blooms in late winter and early spring, often used as an ornamental and for cut flowers.
plants.location: Southeastern Australia, cultivated in Mediterranean climates
plants.funFact: Acacia dealbata is widely celebrated in Mediterranean countries, especially Italy, during International Women's Day where its yellow flowers are gifted to women.

plants.description: A hybrid shrub known for blooming in winter with bright yellow flowers in dense clusters followed by blue-black berries. It is popular in gardens for winter color and its holly-like evergreen leaves.
plants.location: Cultivated gardens, originating from hybrids in Asia
plants.funFact: Mahonia flowers are an important nectar source for bees during winter months when few other flowers bloom.
